questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about first-degree atrioventricular block?

choices.text: Minor Jones criteria in Rheumatic fever
Consistent PR interval with no missed beats

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serial prolongation of PR interval

Explanation:

In the first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block, the PR interval is prolonged and greater than 200 msec but does not show serial increment unlike Mobitz I heart block. Aschoff nodules can involve the conduction system of the heart leading to PR prolongation and is a minor Jones criteria. It can be physiological due to high vagal tone in athletes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man treated with PCI for STEMI develops syncope and is found to have a 2:1 AV block with broad QRS on his ECG. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism behind his AV block, and how would atropine administration affect his condition?

choices.text: The block is most likely in the AV node, and atropine will improve AV conduction.
The block is most likely in the His-Purkinje system, and atropine will improve AV conduction.
The block is most likely in the AV node, and atropine may increase the degree of AV block.
The block is most likely in the His-Purkinje system, and atropine may increase the degree of AV block.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The block is most likely in the His-Purkinje system, and atropine may increase the degree of AV block.

Explanation:

  • 2:1 block is the differential diagnosis of Mobitz II and has lesion at the Bundle of his.
  • The widened QRS complex is suggestive of a block in the His-Purkinje system rather than the AV node.
  • Atropine works at AV node by reducing AV block and enhances conduction through the AV node
  • But here the lesion is in His-Purkinje system, so atropine has no effect or it may increase the block.
  • Atropine will increase sinus firing rate causing increase in AV nodal conduction delay which will add to fixed conduction delay explaining the worsening of this block

 

2:1 Heart block:

It is a condition where there is intermittent failure of conduction between the atrium and ventricle, resulting in every alternate atrial impulse being conducted to the ventricles. This means for every two P waves on an ECG, there is only one QRS complex.

questions.text:
Which among the following are included in the criteria for Metabolic syndrome

1) Waist circumference > 102 cm in men

2) Waist circumference > 88 cm in women

3) HDL > 50 mg/dL in men

4) BP 115/80 mm Hg

5) Fasting plasma glucose > 100 mg/dL

6) LDL > 200 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C)1,2,5

Explanation:

LDL is not a part of the criteria. HDL > 50 will be protective rather. BP is normal. Only Waist circumference > 102 cms (men) & > 88 cms (women) and Fasting plasma glucose > 100 mg/dL among the given options are part of Metabolic syndrome (Syndrome-X) criteria.

 

Metabolic syndrome/Syndrome-X criteria:

1) Waist circumference

> 102 cm in Men

> 88 cmin Women

2) HDL levels

< 40 mg/dL in Men

< 50 mg/dL in Women

3) Triglyceride levels

> 150 mg/dL

4) BP (Blood Pressure)

> 130/85 mmHg

5) Fasting plasma glucose

> 100 mg/dL

 

Extra mile  

Syndrome-Z: Syndrome-X +Obstructive Sleep Apnoea

questions.text: Drug causing maximum mortality reduction in a patient with HFrEF?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Ramipril

Explanation:

The major mortality reducing drug in chronic heart failure is ACEI followed by Beta blockers. SGLT2i's cardiorenal benefit was causing salt loss in urine and causing reduction of SBP by 5 mm Hg.

The recent PARADIGM-HF Trial showed that Sacubitril-Valsartan reduced CV death and HF hospitalization more than Enalapril.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset breathlessness. On arrival his vitals were, PR- 130 bpm, BP- 180/110 mmHg and spO2- 82% in room air. X-ray done is as shown below.What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Furosemide and NTG

Explanation:

X-ray shows perihilar infiltrates with increased interstitial markings due to an increase in hydrostatic pressure in vessels. Due to a hypertensive crisis, this patient is developing acute pulmonary edema due to LV failure. Prompt administration of Furosemide will reduce pulmonary edema. NTG is the drug of choice for Hypertensive crisis in LVF as it lowers BP and also reduces pulmonary edema. Beta blockers are contraindicated in Acute Heart failure. Negative inotropic effects of diltiazem will worsen this patient. Digoxin is not used nowadays due to safer alternatives.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is a known case of triple vessel disease, presented with fatigue. Echocardiography done showed global reduction in contractility and reduced ejection fraction. What is the most likely electrolyte disturbance seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Hyponatremia and Hypokalemia

Explanation:

The patient has developed ischemic cardiomyopathy due to triple vessel disease and going into biventricular heart failure ( global hypokinesia on Echocardiography)

Due to RAAS activation potassium will be low. Another reason can be the use of diuretics in these patients

Due to low BP, increased release of ADH will cause dilutional hyponatremia. Though RAAS is activated , excess of water as compared to sodium will worsen this hyponatremia. CHF has Hypervolemic Hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male comes with complaints of shortness of breath that worsens upon lying down for the past 1 week. On examination, pulse-130 bpm, BP-150/90 mmHg, neck veins are distended, S3+ on cardiac auscultation. He had developed MI last year and was treated. CXR is shown below. Which among the following is not part of the major Framingham's criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) HR-130 bpm

Explanation:

  • Tachycardia can occur in even anxiety or panic attacks and is a minor framingham criteria . S3, Orthopnea and distended neck veins are major diagnostic criteria for heart failure. CXR shows a pacemaker with two leads. The patient could have developed a heart block after his last cardiac event.

 

Framingham diagnostic criteria for Heart Failure:

Major criteria

Minor criteria

Acute pulmonary edema (crepitations/rales)

Cardiomegaly

PND/Orthopnoea

Elevated JVP, positive abdominojugular reflex

S3 gallop rhythm

Weight loss of > 4.5 kg in last 5 days

Ankle edema (pitting pedal edema)

Dyspnoea on exertion

Hepatomegaly

Nocturnal cough

Pleural effusion

Tachycardia (HR>120 bpm)

questions.text: A 68-year-old male is presented with sudden loss of consciousness and collapses. ECG on arrival at ER is shown below and significant perioral pallor was noted while tracing was being done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Third-degree atrioventricular block

Explanation:

The ECG shows number of P waves exceeding no of R waves with complete AV dissociation, which is indicative of third-degree atrioventricular block. It is also called Stokes Adam syndrome. Low cardiac output explains perioral pallor and death-like appearance during attack.

Third-degree atrioventricular block

Ventricular Activity

Maintained by an escape rhythm from:

Distal Purkinje tissues that explains broad QRS complexes

Clinical Features

- Recurrent syncope

- Pallor and a death-like appearance during the attack; characteristic flush upon recovery.

- Rapid recovery distinguishes it from post-ictal deficit of epilepsy

Management

- Permanent pacemaker.

questions.text: Identify the type of heart block from the ECG given below.

choices.text: 2nd degree heart block, intra nodal conduction delay
2nd degree heart block, Infra nodal conduction delay

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2nd degree heart block, intranodal conduction delay

 

Explanation:

Given ECG shows progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs, which indicates Mobitz type I block / 2nd degree heart block with intranodal conduction delay/ Weckneback phenomenon.

 

Second-degree heart block

Dropped beats occur because some impulses from the atria fail to be transmitted to the ventricles.

Types

Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach) 

Mobitz Type II 

Description

Progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs.

PR interval remains constant until a dropped beat occurs

questions.text: A 68-year-old smoker presents with breathing trouble and sudden onset palpitations. The ECG is given below and has an irregular rhythm with an average heart rate of 150 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia

Explanation:

ECG Shows variable RR interval with P waves that rules out atrial fibrillation. On close observation P waves( vertical arrows) are having variable morphology. The diagnosis is MAT. Smokers develop COPD and resultant hypoxia is the trigger for development of this arrhythmia.

Atrial flutter has saw-tooth waves. Sinus tachycardia has reduced RR interval with T wave and P wave visible independently.

questions.text: Which of the following statements on transvenous pacing is wrong?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Permanent method of pacing

Explanation:

Transvenous pacing is a temporary pacing method for symptomatic bradycardia. Inferior wall MI leads to vagus nerve irritation and severe bradycardia that may not respond to atropine.

 

Aspect

Transcutaneous Pacing

Transvenous Pacing

Purpose

Temporary, fast initiation for symptomatic bradyarrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

Longer-term temporary pacing for evaluation of permanent pacemaker need. 

Initiation Time

Fastest method, used in emergencies (e.g., bradycardia, asystole).

Requires more time due to the need for central venous access.

Electrode Placement

Anterior pad: cardiac apex or lead V3 position.

Posterior pad: inferior to scapula or between scapula and spine.


 

Intracardiac lead placement through a central vein (e.g., femoral, subclavian).

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with an inferior wall STEMI. He starts developing altered mental status and heart rate is 38 bpm, blood pressure 80/50 mmHg. Which of the following will be used to manage his bradycadia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IV atropine 1 mg every 3-5 minutes

Explanation:

Altered mental status implies the patient has hemodynamically unstable bradycardia and the treatment is IV atropine 1 mg every 3-5 minutes. In older guidelines the dose was 0.5 mg for a maximum of 6 doses and now it is 1 mg per dose to maximum of 3 doses. The total maximum dose of 3 mg remains the same.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of fatigue and daily headaches is found to have a blood pressure 150/100 mmHg on multiple occasions. His chest X-ray shows cardiomegaly and echocardiography shows reduced mitral inflow with concentric hypertrophy of heart. Which of the following is correct about this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diastolic dysfunction of Left ventricle

Explanation:

 

The key words in question are reduced mitral inflow and concentric hypertrophy of heart that indicates diastolic malfunction of LV due to hypertension of long standing duration. The increased LV end diastolic pressure explains why mitral inflow is reduced. Mitral stenosis is ruled out as it does not have hypertrophy of LV and neither has hypertension. It causes left atria dilation. Mitral regurgitation will cause eccentric hypertrophy.

 

 

Wall thickness

Chamber size

Causes

Concentric hypertrophy

increased

Normal to reduced

Hypertension

Eccentric hypertrophy

Normal

Dilated

Mitral regurgitation

Aortic regurgitation

questions.text:
You are performing an annual medical check up of a 48-year-old man corporate executive. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB)

Explanation:

The patient is asymptomatic and ECG shows rsR' pattern (rabbit ears) in lead V1, a wide QRS (>120 ms), and a broad S wave in leads I and V6. These are classic features for RBBB.

Brugada is ruled out as it has Coved or saddle back ST segment elevation. VT is ruled as the heart rate is normal. LBBB occurs commonly after MI has deep S is lead V1 and notched R showing rabbit ear pattern in V5, V6.

questions.text: A 60 year old man presents with central chest pain and breathing difficulty for the last 6 hours. He had tested positive for RT-PCR SARS COV-2 yesterday. Auscultation shows bilateral basal crepitations. ECG shows non- specific ST segment changes. Both NT pro-BNP levels and Troponin I levels are elevated. In cath lab coronary angiography is normal. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Myocarditis

Explanation:

 

Key words are normal coronary angiography that rules out MI. Presence of non specific ST segment changes with elevated NT-ProBNP and troponin I indicates myocardial damage by COVID 19. Myocarditis is causing chest pain and features of pulmonary edema. Broken heart syndrome requires intense emotional trauma and catecholamine excess. Option D is ruled out as it has global ST-segment elevation with concavity upwards.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male develops MI and is taken up for thrombolysis in the district hospital. ECG shows which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB)

Explanation:

Post MI the patient has developed LBBB. ECG shows a widened QRS complex (>120 ms), a broad and notched R wave in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6 (lateral leads), and a deep S wave in V1 and V2. The lack of Q waves in the lateral leads is also typical.

questions.text: Calculate the heart rate of the ECG shown below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 60 beats per minute

Explanation:

There are 5 large boxes separating peaks of R waves.

Heart Rate = 300/Number of Large Boxes between R-R interval or 1500/ Number of small boxes between R-R interval

Heart rate = 300/5=60 beats per minute

questions.text: A 65-year-old smoker with COPD presents to the ER with palpitations and shortness of breath. His ECG shows an irregular rhythm with at least three distinct P-wave morphologies and a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. BP 100/60 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate management to prevent recurrence of this rythm disorder
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) LTOT with LAMA and LABA

Explanation:

Multifocal atrial tachycardia is often triggered by acute illnesses and hypoxia in patients with COPD. Long term oxygen therapy using oxygen concentrator LAMA and LABA will address hypoxia that is the trigger for development of this dysrhythmia.
